If an object is provided for `callback` the created "_.where" style callback will return `true` for elements that have the properties of the given object, else `false`. ##### Parameters | Name | Type | Description | | | ---- | ---- | ----------- | -------- | | array | `Array` | The array to process. |   | | isSorted=false | `boolean` | A flag to indicate that `array` is sorted. | *Optional* | | callback=identity | `Function` `Object` `string` | The function called per iteration. If a property name or object is provided it will be used to create a "_.pluck" or "_.where" style callback, respectively. | *Optional* | | thisArg | | The `this` binding of `callback`. | *Optional* | ##### Examples ```javascript _.uniq([1, 2, 1, 3, 1]); // => [1, 2, 3] _.uniq([1, 1, 2, 2, 3], true); // => [1, 2, 3] _.uniq(['A', 'b', 'C', 'a', 'B', 'c'], function(letter) { return letter.toLowerCase(); }); // => ['A', 'b', 'C'] _.uniq([1, 2.5, 3, 1.5, 2, 3.5], function(num) { return this.floor(num); }, Math); // => [1, 2.5, 3] // using "_.pluck" callback shorthand _.uniq([{ 'x': 1 }, { 'x': 2 }, { 'x': 1 }], 'x'); // => [{ 'x': 1 }, { 'x': 2 }] ``` ##### Returns - `Array` Returns a duplicate-value-free array. #### without(array[, value]) Creates an array excluding all provided values using strict equality for comparisons, i.e. `===`. ##### Parameters | Name | Type | Description | | | ---- | ---- | ----------- | -------- | | array | `Array` | The array to filter. |   | | value | | The values to exclude. | *Optional* | ##### Examples ```javascript _.without([1, 2, 1, 0, 3, 1, 4], 0, 1); // => [2, 3, 4] ``` ##### Returns - `Array` Returns a new array of filtered values. #### xor([array]) Creates an array that is the symmetric difference of the provided arrays. See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetric_difference. ##### Parameters | Name | Type | Description | | | ---- | ---- | ----------- | -------- | | array | `Array` | The arrays to inspect. | *Optional* | ##### Examples ```javascript _.xor([1, 2, 3], [5, 2, 1, 4]); // => [3, 5, 4] _.xor([1, 2, 5], [2, 3, 5], [3, 4, 5]); // => [1, 4, 5] ``` ##### Returns - `Array` Returns an array of values. #### zip([array]) Creates an array of grouped elements, the first of which contains the first elements of the given arrays, the second of which contains the second elements of the given arrays, and so on. ##### Parameters | Name | Type | Description | | | ---- | ---- | ----------- | -------- | | array | `Array` | Arrays to process. | *Optional* | ##### Examples ```javascript _.zip(['fred', 'barney'], [30, 40], [true, false]); // => [['fred', 30, true], ['barney', 40, false]] ``` ##### Returns - `Array` Returns a new array of grouped elements. #### zipObject(keys[, values=]) Creates an object composed from arrays of `keys` and `values`. Provide either a single two dimensional array, i.e. `[[key1, value1], [key2, value2]]` or two arrays, one of `keys` and one of corresponding `values`. ##### Parameters | Name | Type | Description | | | ---- | ---- | ----------- | -------- | | keys | `Array` | The array of keys. |   | | values= | `Array` | The array of values. | *Optional* | ##### Examples ```javascript _.zipObject(['fred', 'barney'], [30, 40]); // => { 'fred': 30, 'barney': 40 } ``` ##### Returns - `Object` Returns an object composed of the given keys and corresponding values. #### after(n, func) Creates a function that executes `func`, with the `this` binding and arguments of the created function, only after being called `n` times. ##### Parameters | Name | Type | Description | | | ---- | ---- | ----------- | -------- | | n | `number` | The number of times the function must be called before `func` is executed. |   | | func | `Function` | The function to restrict. |   | ##### Examples ```javascript var saves = ['profile', 'settings']; var done = _.after(saves.length, function() { console.log('Done saving!'); }); _.forEach(saves, function(type) { asyncSave({ 'type': type, 'complete': done }); }); // => logs 'Done saving!', after all saves have completed ``` ##### Returns - `Function` Returns the new restricted function. #### bind(func[, thisArg, arg]) Creates a function that, when called, invokes `func` with the `this` binding of `thisArg` and prepends any additional `bind` arguments to those provided to the bound function. ##### Parameters | Name | Type | Description | | | ---- | ---- | ----------- | -------- | | func | `Function` | The function to bind. |   | | thisArg | | The `this` binding of `func`. | *Optional* | | arg | | Arguments to be partially applied. | *Optional* | ##### Examples ```javascript var func = function(greeting) { return greeting + ' ' + this.name; }; func = _.bind(func, { 'name': 'fred' }, 'hi'); func(); // => 'hi fred' ``` ##### Returns - `Function` Returns the new bound function. #### bindAll(object[, methodName]) Binds methods of an object to the object itself, overwriting the existing method. Method names may be specified as individual arguments or as arrays of method names. If no method names are provided all the function properties of `object` will be bound. ##### Parameters | Name | Type | Description | | | ---- | ---- | ----------- | -------- | | object | `Object` | The object to bind and assign the bound methods to. |   | | methodName | `string` | The object method names to bind, specified as individual method names or arrays of method names. | *Optional* | ##### Examples ```javascript var view = { 'label': 'docs', 'onClick': function() { console.log('clicked ' + this.label); } }; _.bindAll(view); jQuery('#docs').on('click', view.onClick); // => logs 'clicked docs', when the button is clicked ``` ##### Returns - `Object` Returns `object`. #### bindKey(object, key[, arg]) Creates a function that, when called, invokes the method at `object[key]` and prepends any additional `bindKey` arguments to those provided to the bound function. This method differs from `_.bind` by allowing bound functions to reference methods that will be redefined or don't yet exist. See http://michaux.ca/articles/lazy-function-definition-pattern. ##### Parameters | Name | Type | Description | | | ---- | ---- | ----------- | -------- | | object | `Object` | The object the method belongs to. |   | | key | `string` | The key of the method. |   | | arg | | Arguments to be partially applied. | *Optional* | ##### Examples ```javascript var object = { 'name': 'fred', 'greet': function(greeting) { return greeting + ' ' + this.name; } }; var func = _.bindKey(object, 'greet', 'hi'); func(); // => 'hi fred' object.greet = function(greeting) { return greeting + 'ya ' + this.name + '!'; }; func(); // => 'hiya fred!' ``` ##### Returns - `Function` Returns the new bound function. #### compose([func]) Creates a function that is the composition of the provided functions, where each function consumes the return value of the function that follows. For example, composing the functions `f()`, `g()`, and `h()` produces `f(g(h()))`. Each function is executed with the `this` binding of the composed function. ##### Parameters | Name | Type | Description | | | ---- | ---- | ----------- | -------- | | func | `Function` | Functions to compose. | *Optional* | ##### Examples ```javascript var realNameMap = { 'pebbles': 'penelope' }; var format = function(name) { name = realNameMap[name.toLowerCase()] || name; return name.charAt(0).toUpperCase() + name.slice(1).toLowerCase(); }; var greet = function(formatted) { return 'Hiya ' + formatted + '!'; }; var welcome = _.compose(greet, format); welcome('pebbles'); // => 'Hiya Penelope!' ``` ##### Returns - `Function` Returns the new composed function. #### curry(func) Creates a function which accepts one or more arguments of `func` that when invoked either executes `func` returning its result, if all `func` arguments have been provided, or returns a function that accepts one or more of the remaining `func` arguments, and so on. The arity of `func` can be specified if `func.length` is not sufficient. ##### Parameters | Name | Type | Description | | | ---- | ---- | ----------- | -------- | | func | `Function` | The function to curry. |   | | arity=func.length | `number` | The arity of `func`. | *Optional* | ##### Examples ```javascript var curried = _.curry(function(a, b, c) { console.log(a + b + c); }); curried(1)(2)(3); // => 6 curried(1, 2)(3); // => 6 curried(1, 2, 3); // => 6 ``` ##### Returns - `Function` Returns the new curried function. #### debounce(func, wait[, options]) Creates a function that will delay the execution of `func` until after `wait` milliseconds have elapsed since the last time it was invoked. Provide an options object to indicate that `func` should be invoked on the leading and/or trailing edge of the `wait` timeout. Subsequent calls to the debounced function will return the result of the last `func` call. Note: If `leading` and `trailing` options are `true` `func` will be called on the trailing edge of the timeout only if the the debounced function is invoked more than once during the `wait` timeout. ##### Parameters | Name | Type | Description | | | ---- | ---- | ----------- | -------- | | func | `Function` | The function to debounce. |   | | wait | `number` | The number of milliseconds to delay. |   | | options | `Object` | The options object. | *Optional* | | options.leading=false | `boolean` | Specify execution on the leading edge of the timeout. | *Optional* | | options.maxWait | `number` | The maximum time `func` is allowed to be delayed before it's called. | *Optional* | | options.trailing=true | `boolean` | Specify execution on the trailing edge of the timeout. | *Optional* | ##### Examples ```javascript // avoid costly calculations while the window size is in flux var lazyLayout = _.debounce(calculateLayout, 150); jQuery(window).on('resize', lazyLayout); // execute `sendMail` when the click event is fired, debouncing subsequent calls jQuery('#postbox').on('click', _.debounce(sendMail, 300, { 'leading': true, 'trailing': false }); // ensure `batchLog` is executed once after 1 second of debounced calls var source = new EventSource('/stream'); source.addEventListener('message', _.debounce(batchLog, 250, { 'maxWait': 1000 }, false); ``` ##### Returns - `Function` Returns the new debounced function. #### defer(func[, arg]) Defers executing the `func` function until the current call stack has cleared. Additional arguments will be provided to `func` when it is invoked. ##### Parameters | Name | Type | Description | | | ---- | ---- | ----------- | -------- | | func | `Function` | The function to defer. |   | | arg | | Arguments to invoke the function with. | *Optional* | ##### Examples ```javascript _.defer(function(text) { console.log(text); }, 'deferred'); // logs 'deferred' after one or more milliseconds ``` ##### Returns - `number` Returns the timer id. #### delay(func, wait[, arg]) Executes the `func` function after `wait` milliseconds. Additional arguments will be provided to `func` when it is invoked. ##### Parameters | Name | Type | Description | | | ---- | ---- | ----------- | -------- | | func | `Function` | The function to delay. |   | | wait | `number` | The number of milliseconds to delay execution. |   | | arg | | Arguments to invoke the function with. | *Optional* | ##### Examples ```javascript _.delay(function(text) { console.log(text); }, 1000, 'later'); // => logs 'later' after one second ``` ##### Returns - `number` Returns the timer id. #### memoize(func[, resolver]) Creates a function that memoizes the result of `func`. If `resolver` is provided it will be used to determine the cache key for storing the result based on the arguments provided to the memoized function. By default, the first argument provided to the memoized function is used as the cache key. The `func` is executed with the `this` binding of the memoized function. The result cache is exposed as the `cache` property on the memoized function. ##### Parameters | Name | Type | Description | | | ---- | ---- | ----------- | -------- | | func | `Function` | The function to have its output memoized. |   | | resolver | `Function` | A function used to resolve the cache key. | *Optional* | ##### Examples ```javascript var fibonacci = _.memoize(function(n) { return n < 2 ? n : fibonacci(n - 1) + fibonacci(n - 2); }); fibonacci(9) // => 34 var data = { 'fred': { 'name': 'fred', 'age': 40 }, 'pebbles': { 'name': 'pebbles', 'age': 1 } }; // modifying the result cache var get = _.memoize(function(name) { return data[name]; }, _.identity); get('pebbles'); // => { 'name': 'pebbles', 'age': 1 } get.cache.pebbles.name = 'penelope'; get('pebbles'); // => { 'name': 'penelope', 'age': 1 } ``` ##### Returns - `Function` Returns the new memoizing function. #### once(func) Creates a function that is restricted to execute `func` once. Repeat calls to the function will return the value of the first call. The `func` is executed with the `this` binding of the created function. ##### Parameters | Name | Type | Description | | | ---- | ---- | ----------- | -------- | | func | `Function` | The function to restrict. |   | ##### Examples ```javascript var initialize = _.once(createApplication); initialize(); initialize(); // `initialize` executes `createApplication` once ``` ##### Returns - `Function` Returns the new restricted function. #### partial(func[, arg]) Creates a function that, when called, invokes `func` with any additional `partial` arguments prepended to those provided to the new function. This method is similar to `_.bind` except it does **not** alter the `this` binding. ##### Parameters | Name | Type | Description | | | ---- | ---- | ----------- | -------- | | func | `Function` | The function to partially apply arguments to. |   | | arg | | Arguments to be partially applied. | *Optional* | ##### Examples ```javascript var greet = function(greeting, name) { return greeting + ' ' + name; }; var hi = _.partial(greet, 'hi'); hi('fred'); // => 'hi fred' ``` ##### Returns - `Function` Returns the new partially applied function. #### partialRight(func[, arg]) This method is like `_.partial` except that `partial` arguments are appended to those provided to the new function. ##### Parameters | Name | Type | Description | | | ---- | ---- | ----------- | -------- | | func | `Function` | The function to partially apply arguments to. |   | | arg | | Arguments to be partially applied. | *Optional* | ##### Examples ```javascript var defaultsDeep = _.partialRight(_.merge, _.defaults); var options = { 'variable': 'data', 'imports': { 'jq': $ } }; defaultsDeep(options, _.templateSettings); options.variable // => 'data' options.imports // => { '_': _, 'jq': $ } ``` ##### Returns - `Function` Returns the new partially applied function. #### throttle(func, wait[, options]) Creates a function that, when executed, will only call the `func` function at most once per every `wait` milliseconds. Provide an options object to indicate that `func` should be invoked on the leading and/or trailing edge of the `wait` timeout. Subsequent calls to the throttled function will return the result of the last `func` call. Note: If `leading` and `trailing` options are `true` `func` will be called on the trailing edge of the timeout only if the the throttled function is invoked more than once during the `wait` timeout. ##### Parameters | Name | Type | Description | | | ---- | ---- | ----------- | -------- | | func | `Function` | The function to throttle. |   | | wait | `number` | The number of milliseconds to throttle executions to. |   | | options | `Object` | The options object. | *Optional* | | options.leading=true | `boolean` | Specify execution on the leading edge of the timeout. | *Optional* | | options.trailing=true | `boolean` | Specify execution on the trailing edge of the timeout. | *Optional* | ##### Examples ```javascript // avoid excessively updating the position while scrolling var throttled = _.throttle(updatePosition, 100); jQuery(window).on('scroll', throttled); // execute `renewToken` when the click event is fired, but not more than once every 5 minutes jQuery('.interactive').on('click', _.throttle(renewToken, 300000, { 'trailing': false })); ``` ##### Returns - `Function` Returns the new throttled function. #### wrap(value, wrapper) Creates a function that provides `value` to the wrapper function as its first argument. Additional arguments provided to the function are appended to those provided to the wrapper function. The wrapper is executed with the `this` binding of the created function. ##### Parameters | Name | Type | Description | | | ---- | ---- | ----------- | -------- | | value | | The value to wrap. |   | | wrapper | `Function` | The wrapper function. |   | ##### Examples ```javascript var p = _.wrap(_.escape, function(func, text) { return '

' + func(text) + '

'; }); p('Fred, Wilma, & Pebbles'); // => '

Fred, Wilma, & Pebbles

' ``` ##### Returns - `Function` Returns the new function. #### constant(value) Creates a function that returns `value`. ##### Parameters | Name | Type | Description | | | ---- | ---- | ----------- | -------- | | value | | The value to return from the new function. |   | ##### Examples ```javascript var object = { 'name': 'fred' }; var getter = _.constant(object); getter() === object; // => true ``` ##### Returns - `Function` Returns the new function. #### createCallback([func=identity, thisArg, argCount]) Produces a callback bound to an optional `thisArg`. If `func` is a property name the created callback will return the property value for a given element. If `func` is an object the created callback will return `true` for elements that contain the equivalent object properties, otherwise it will return `false`. ##### Parameters | Name | Type | Description | | | ---- | ---- | ----------- | -------- | | func=identity | | The value to convert to a callback. | *Optional* | | thisArg | | The `this` binding of the created callback. | *Optional* | | argCount | `number` | The number of arguments the callback accepts. | *Optional* | ##### Examples ```javascript var characters = [ { 'name': 'barney', 'age': 36 }, { 'name': 'fred', 'age': 40 } ]; // wrap to create custom callback shorthands _.createCallback = _.wrap(_.createCallback, function(func, callback, thisArg) { var match = /^(.+?)__([gl]t)(.+)$/.exec(callback); return !match ? func(callback, thisArg) : function(object) { return match[2] == 'gt' ? object[match[1]] > match[3] : object[match[1]] < match[3]; }; }); _.filter(characters, 'age__gt38'); // => [{ 'name': 'fred', 'age': 40 }] ``` ##### Returns - `Function` Returns a callback function. #### escape(string) Converts the characters `&`, `<`, `>`, `"`, and `'` in `string` to their corresponding HTML entities. ##### Parameters | Name | Type | Description | | | ---- | ---- | ----------- | -------- | | string | `string` | The string to escape. |   | ##### Examples ```javascript _.escape('Fred, Wilma, & Pebbles'); // => 'Fred, Wilma, & Pebbles' ``` ##### Returns - `string` Returns the escaped string. #### identity(value) This method returns the first argument provided to it. ##### Parameters | Name | Type | Description | | | ---- | ---- | ----------- | -------- | | value | | Any value. |   | ##### Examples ```javascript var object = { 'name': 'fred' }; _.identity(object) === object; // => true ``` ##### Returns - Returns `value`. #### mixin([object=lodash], source[, options]) Adds function properties of a source object to the destination object. If `object` is a function methods will be added to its prototype as well. ##### Parameters | Name | Type | Description | | | ---- | ---- | ----------- | -------- | | object=lodash | `Function` `Object` | object The destination object. | *Optional* | | source | `Object` | The object of functions to add. |   | | options | `Object` | The options object. | *Optional* | | options.chain=true | `boolean` | Specify whether the functions added are chainable. | *Optional* | ##### Examples ```javascript function capitalize(string) { return string.charAt(0).toUpperCase() + string.slice(1).toLowerCase(); } _.mixin({ 'capitalize': capitalize }); _.capitalize('fred'); // => 'Fred' _('fred').capitalize().value(); // => 'Fred' _.mixin({ 'capitalize': capitalize }, { 'chain': false }); _('fred').capitalize(); // => 'Fred' ``` ##### Returns - `Void` #### noConflict() Reverts the '_' variable to its previous value and returns a reference to the `lodash` function. ##### Examples ```javascript var lodash = _.noConflict(); ``` ##### Returns - `Function` Returns the `lodash` function. #### noop() A no-operation function. ##### Examples ```javascript var object = { 'name': 'fred' }; _.noop(object) === undefined; // => true ``` ##### Returns - `Void` #### now() Gets the number of milliseconds that have elapsed since the Unix epoch (1 January 1970 00:00:00 UTC). ##### Examples ```javascript var stamp = _.now(); _.defer(function() { console.log(_.now() - stamp); }); // => logs the number of milliseconds it took for the deferred function to be called ``` ##### Returns - `Void` #### parseInt(value[, radix]) Converts the given value into an integer of the specified radix. If `radix` is `undefined` or `0` a `radix` of `10` is used unless the `value` is a hexadecimal, in which case a `radix` of `16` is used. Note: This method avoids differences in native ES3 and ES5 `parseInt` implementations. See http://es5.github.io/#E. ##### Parameters | Name | Type | Description | | | ---- | ---- | ----------- | -------- | | value | `string` | The value to parse. |   | | radix | `number` | The radix used to interpret the value to parse. | *Optional* | ##### Examples ```javascript _.parseInt('08'); // => 8 ``` ##### Returns - `number` Returns the new integer value. #### property(key) Creates a "_.pluck" style function, which returns the `key` value of a given object. ##### Parameters | Name | Type | Description | | | ---- | ---- | ----------- | -------- | | key | `string` | The name of the property to retrieve. |   | ##### Examples ```javascript var characters = [ { 'name': 'fred', 'age': 40 }, { 'name': 'barney', 'age': 36 } ]; var getName = _.property('name'); _.map(characters, getName); // => ['barney', 'fred'] _.sortBy(characters, getName); // => [{ 'name': 'barney', 'age': 36 }, { 'name': 'fred', 'age': 40 }] ``` ##### Returns - `Function` Returns the new function. #### random([min=0, max=1, floating=false]) Produces a random number between `min` and `max` (inclusive). If only one argument is provided a number between `0` and the given number will be returned. If `floating` is truey or either `min` or `max` are floats a floating-point number will be returned instead of an integer. ##### Parameters | Name | Type | Description | | | ---- | ---- | ----------- | -------- | | min=0 | `number` | The minimum possible value. | *Optional* | | max=1 | `number` | The maximum possible value. | *Optional* | | floating=false | `boolean` | Specify returning a floating-point number. | *Optional* | ##### Examples ```javascript _.random(0, 5); // => an integer between 0 and 5 _.random(5); // => also an integer between 0 and 5 _.random(5, true); // => a floating-point number between 0 and 5 _.random(1.2, 5.2); // => a floating-point number between 1.2 and 5.2 ``` ##### Returns - `number` Returns a random number. #### result(object, key) Resolves the value of property `key` on `object`. If `key` is a function it will be invoked with the `this` binding of `object` and its result returned, else the property value is returned. If `object` is falsey then `undefined` is returned. ##### Parameters | Name | Type | Description | | | ---- | ---- | ----------- | -------- | | object | `Object` | The object to inspect. |   | | key | `string` | The name of the property to resolve. |   | ##### Examples ```javascript var object = { 'cheese': 'crumpets', 'stuff': function() { return 'nonsense'; } }; _.result(object, 'cheese'); // => 'crumpets' _.result(object, 'stuff'); // => 'nonsense' ``` ##### Returns - Returns the resolved value. #### template(text, data[, options, sourceURL, variable]) A micro-templating method that handles arbitrary delimiters, preserves whitespace, and correctly escapes quotes within interpolated code. Note: In the development build, `_.template` utilizes sourceURLs for easier debugging. See http://www.html5rocks.com/en/tutorials/developertools/sourcemaps/#toc-sourceurl For more information on precompiling templates see: http://lodash.com/custom-builds For more information on Chrome extension sandboxes see: http://developer.chrome.com/stable/extensions/sandboxingEval.html ##### Parameters | Name | Type | Description | | | ---- | ---- | ----------- | -------- | | text | `string` | The template text. |   | | data | `Object` | The data object used to populate the text. |   | | options | `Object` | The options object. | *Optional* | | options.escape | `RegExp` | The "escape" delimiter. | *Optional* | | options.evaluate | `RegExp` | The "evaluate" delimiter. | *Optional* | | options.imports | `Object` | An object to import into the template as local variables. | *Optional* | | options.interpolate | `RegExp` | The "interpolate" delimiter. | *Optional* | | sourceURL | `string` | The sourceURL of the template's compiled source. | *Optional* | | variable | `string` | The data object variable name. | *Optional* | ##### Examples ```javascript // using the "interpolate" delimiter to create a compiled template var compiled = _.template('hello <%= name %>'); compiled({ 'name': 'fred' }); // => 'hello fred' // using the "escape" delimiter to escape HTML in data property values _.template('<%- value %>', { 'value': '
